name_en: Protect the Caribbean Sea
short_description_en: Honduras is one of the most vulnerable countries in the world to climate change. In the last decade, it was the second country most affected by hurricanes, storms or floods. This project aims to reduce coastal degradation and improve the quality of life of the inhabitants.
description_en: This biodiversity conservation initiative will be developed in the System of Protected Areas of the Southern Honduras Zone (SAPZsurH), a territory highly vulnerable to climatic phenomena, such as drought and floods. It is a transversal project which includes several conservation and restoration activities of the species and ecosystems of this territory including reforestation, education and training of the population. The economic activities of the population focus on agriculture, animal husbandry and fishing, which are carried out intensively. Extreme poverty is one of the main problems affecting the population, along with a high rate of youth migration. Extractive projects and agro-industry exert strong pressure on natural resources, mainly mangroves and water bodies. The Forest Conservation Institute (ICF) estimates that 52% of mangrove forest cover has been lost over the past 16 years. The proliferation of solid wastes resulting from their mismanagement is also a major problem. In the urban area of ​​the Municipality of Marcovia alone, around 3,195 tons of waste are produced each year, only a part of which is collected due to lack of municipal resources and a sanitary landfill. On the other hand, the agro-industry established in this municipality generates 500 tons of plastic per year which are deposited in landfills; causing a significant emission of 600,154 Kg of CO2 per year into the atmosphere.

name_en: Restore French forests
short_description_en: The project is the result of a collective reflection by actors in the forest-wood sector to face the challenges of our forests. These now need to adapt to climate change and fight against the fall of forest plantations. However, public aid to french forests is low, with forests in the Center-Val-de-Loire receiving no planting aid. Duramen therefore aims to support tree plantations, strengthening the resilience of forests and their biodiversity.
description_en:
To adapt forests to climate change, preserve and strengthen the sustainable management of their ecosystem, the Duramen association financially supports plantation projects. These projects, with an environmental added value, are led by private or public forest owners in the Center-Val de Loire region. These projects focus on reforestation projects on wasteland or abandoned farmland or the transformations of poor or dying populations. By doing so, Duramen acts for the preservation of these reservoirs of biodiversity.

Duramen intends to be the trigger of planting projects. Its objective is to support these projects with an aid of up to 2000€ per hectare. This can be decisive for the owner and trigger planting projects that would otherwise not have taken place. Since its creation, the project has supported the planting of more than 118,000 trees and the preservation of 110 hectares of forest.

name_en: Offer sports scholarships to sick children
short_description_en: The project aims at offering children with cancer in Spain the possibility of training and doing sport, and in this way, helping them to recover energy and smile to face the disease better.
description_en: Every year 1,400 new cases of childhood cancer are diagnosed in Spain. Physical exercise has become a fundamental non-pharmacological tool during treatment and in the subsequent phases of maintenance and monitoring. The practice of sport increases muscle strength, decreases systemic inﬂammation and improves immune function, reducing fatigue. For this reason, Fundación Aladina has developed Sports Scholarships for children with cancer and their caregivers. Through these scholarships they pay for specialized physical exercise therapy for children and adolescents with cancer, taught in a specialized center by Elena Santana, a doctor in Physical Activity and Health. 'Children with cancer should do physical exercise because it helps improve tolerance to treatments and helps alleviate side effects.'. For Christmas and to start this new year, let's make sure that children with cancer do not lose their smile by offering them gift cards for exercising.

name_en: Offer French language courses for refugees and asylum seekers
short_description_en: Lack of French language abilities undermine the possibilities of refugees and asylum seekers to find adequate jobs and, overall, hinders a successful integration.  The French language school, Thot, contributes to the professional and social integration of migrants by offering language classes and cultural activities. They aim at fighting linguistic precariousness.
description_en:
Thot (which translates: transmitting a horizon to all) is a french language school that provides asylum seekers and refugees with the right tools to succeed in their social, economic and professional integration in France.

Classes are open for people who have had little or no schooling in their country. Students get access to a 160-hours French course (per language level) and to professional insertion and cultural workshops. Thot commits to lead its learner to obtain the DILF (initial diploma in French language) and DELF (Diploma in French Language Studies) diplomas. In exchange, students pay a symbolic sum of 7 €.

To make sure that participants can properly benefit from the classes, Thot also offers them support with administrative tasks as well as psychological therapy sessions.

Donations collected through the NooS platform aim at providing hours of quality language training to over 9 refugees or asylum seekers.

name_en: Support exiled women through a mentoring program
short_description_en: Exiled women are among the most vulnerable groups due to a lack of financial means and professional qualifications. This hinders a successful integration in host countries. UniR’s mentoring program fosters the professional and academic integration of exiled women in France.
description_en:
Intercultur'elles is UniR's mentoring program that enhances the career paths of refugee and asylum-seeking women through the development of personal, professional, and academic skills. In an intercultural context, the program helps them define their projects and build the future they desire.

Mentors are local women eager to share their professional and life experiences to empower their mentees. Through individual and group sessions, participants work on specific objectives: women explore their academic and professional background, implement projects that are in line with their background and skills, exploit their potential by working on their self-confidence, and learn to develop a network. Mentors and mentees discover each other's culture and share their experiences with each other.

The participants of the program attend workshops on migration, gender, and interculturality specially designed for this program. The donations collected through NooS support the access of participants to these workshops.

name_en: Train vulnerable women in entrepreneurship
short_description_en: In Sub-Saharan Africa, the poverty rate is very high. Women, who are often at home and inactive, are among those most exposed to precariousness. This project provides micro-finance and entrepreneurship support to bring these vulnerable women towards autonomy.
description_en: Casamance is a region of Senegal scarred by an armed conflict that lasted more than 30 years. Insecurity in the villages has caused significant movements of the population towards the cities (Ziguinchor and Bignona), in deprived, semi-rural, peripheral neighborhoods with no infrastructure. Formal jobs are extremely rare there and people survive by running a small business, a farm, a sewing workshop, etc. Their precarious situation limits their ability to develop and sustain these income-generating activities. Entrepreneurs du Monde contribue to their socioeconomic emancipation. Already active in Senegal since 2008 with Mutuelles d'Epargne et de Crédit, the French NGO created its own social microfinance program FANSOTO in Casamance, in 2016. It helps women to successfully carry out income-generating activities and improve the living conditions of their families. The program offers advice to access financial services (savings and microcredit), training on entrepreneurship and workshops to raise awareness on social issues (health, women's rights). The training helps women manage purchases, calculate resale prices, and act against competition. In addition, it allows them to better understand their rights.

name_en: Support disabled children
short_description_en: Trisomy 21 affects one in 700 pregnancies on average. The most common symptoms are intellectual retardation, poor muscle tone, and delayed language. Support from an early age through physiotherapy and psychomotor skills has proven to be very effective for the development of children.
description_en: Bronchiolitis, pneumonia, colic, chronic constipation, gastroesophageal reflux, sinusitis, otitis…. Children with Down’s syndrome, due to their anatomical and physiological characteristics, are more likely to suffer from certain types of respiratory and digestive pathologies that on many occasions lead to hospital admission with all the complications that this entails in family dynamics, such as family absenteeism from school and work, increased drug intake, inability to enjoy recreational activities ... it prevents them from leading a normal life. The Madrid Down Early Attention Center cares for 179 children from 0 to 6 years old with intellectual disabilities or at risk of suffering from it, as well as their families. In addition to offering global stimulation sessions, physical therapy, speech therapy, psychotherapy and psychomotor skills, it offers specific and personalized respiratory and digestive physiotherapy treatments to prevent children from getting worse and having to be admitted. Families are also advised on the prevention of these alterations.

name_en: Offer food shopping cards to vulnerable families
short_description_en: This project, developed by Action Against Hunger, aims at leaving no one behind. It allows offering shopping cards to families in Spain with little or no resources so that they can buy food and have access to a healthy diet.
description_en: With the socioeconomic crisis amplified by the health crisis produced by Covid-19, Action Against Hunger has developed a new program in Spain to support the people who need it most. The objective is to alleviate the economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis that is affecting thousands of Spanish families. Today, 6 million people are at risk of falling into poverty in Spain. Many of them had never been in need before, but the pandemic has left them without resources to cope. Action Against Hunger has set up an exclusive monetary transfer system (in form of shopping cards) for food expenses focused on healthy food. An average cost of € 346 per month has been estimated. To ensure that the families invest this economic resource in healthy food, awareness-raising actions are carried out. The objective is not to generate a long-term income in the families, but to apply a temporary measure that helps mitigate the effects of the reduction in income on the food security of families in extreme vulnerability.

In addition, the United Nations forecasts that 280 million people will become refugees by 2050 due to our climate crisis. People living in refugee camps stay there for 17 years on average, but only 1% to 3% have access to higher education. CHAMS, a startup NGO, was created to bring tech education and employment to refugees all around the world.  IN 2019, Chams created a first cohort of 30 students in Jordan at ZAATARI camp, the largest refugee camp in the middle east. This cohort welcomes 50% women and 50% men. The Coding School created by Chams offers seven months intensive training for refugees and Jordanian youth vulnerable population. The methodology is based on a blended approach and the content of the program is highly innovative.

name_en: Support the professional reintegration of ex-offenders
short_description_en: An innovative rehabilitation and reintegration program conducted in France by Wake up Café which allows detainees to have continuous support: from preparation within prison to placement in companies. In this way, each <wakeur> can get out of prison in the best possible way and be part of an effective social and professional reintegration process.
description_en: WKF develops “inside-outside” support programs to accompany people who have been detained and prepare them to face the challenges of reintegration without recidivism. During detention, a 3-week release preparation course is offered in collaboration with the penitentiary center. Through four modules, this program aims to support ex-offenders by working on self-knowledge, development of potential, citizenship and commitment, and the conception of a professional project. WKF also offers cultural activities during detention that seek to empower people. Once released, wakeurs (out of prison) become part of the WKF community and participate in daily courses tailored to their specific needs until their return to employment. Every morning, they take part in professional preparation workshops run by partner companies (i.e. understanding company codes and cultures, elaboration of a CV, interviews preparation training, etc.). The afternoon activities focus on self-reconstruction (coffee-philosophy, positive communication, sports, eloquence lessons, art therapy, theater, discovery of the French heritage).

name_en: Train refugee women in digital skills
short_description_en: In 2018, more than 70 million people were forced to flee their homes and become refugees. Refugee women and girls face gender-specific challenges such as discrimination and violence, which hinder their access to education and professional opportunities. This project aims at empowering women through training in digital skills in France, Italy, and Greece while supporting women’s effort in integration.
description_en: Since 2018, Techfugees #TF4Women Fellowship Programme accelerates the professional inclusion of refugee women in the tech industry. The program has been running for two years in France and contributed to the landing of jobs in tech for 80% of participants. Through training sessions, mentorship, and networking events, Techfugees’ fellows benefit during 6 months from technical and professional experiences of actors in the tech industry. Through the program, refugee women are able to further deepen their knowledge in digital marketing, web development, and digital project management. Women improve their abilities to find jobs and feel more confident. Beyond professional development training, Techfugee makes sure that women can attend and dedicate 100% of their energy into the training, by offering essential services such as babysitting, psychological support, transportation, etc.

name_en: Train disadvantaged women entrepreneurs in digital skills
short_description_en: Entrepreneurship is considered to be a key source for economic development and employment generation. However, small businesses often face greater constraints due to a lack of resources. This is even more true for disadvantaged entrepreneurs, such as women or immigrants, as they often have limited skills and face discrimination. Germinal’s scholarship program seeks to empower disadvantaged women entrepreneurs in France; they offer them training in digital skills and business knowledge.
description_en: Germinal is a French company of growth hackers that helps businesses boost their digital marketing operations through online training. The company now aims at making its knowledge accessible to those who needed most. Germinal's team awards scholarships to disadvantaged entrepreneur women that need to boost their businesses or business ideas. Oftentimes, the program's beneficiaries can not afford the training needed to succeed in their endeavors. Some of them are jobless, students with low income or have several children. The one-month Growth Bootcamp trains women in digital marketing skills -from copywriting to B2B prospection- and guides them across the creation of an acquisition strategy. Germinal’s Growth Marketing methodology helps participants test the market, find their first customers, and identify the right growth levers. Acquiring better business knowledge empowers women and, as a result, they are more likely to thrive. Women spend at least 32 hours improving their skills and participate in weekly live workshops that foster exchange and social bonding. Through NooS, you can contribute to funding scholarships for 4 women.

name_en: Support victims of discrimination
short_description_en: The fight for the legal equality of LGBT+ people must move forward. LGBT+ people still face discrimination and negative stereotypes in society. One in eight LGBT+ people has experienced some form of unequal treatment from healthcare staff because they’re LGBT+. This project of the association Stop Homophobie provides medical and mental health care to victims of discrimination.
description_en: STOP homophobie works to tackle damaging stereotypes and discrimination based on gender, sexual orientation, and health status. Their main goal is to protect LGBT+ people, improve their daily life and their living conditions. Through its actions, the association promotes the rights of LGBT+ people and advocate for policy changes. This project provides psychological and legal support to victims of discrimination and violence. The team has two main support channels that victims can use for free to ask for help: a hotline and a website. Both enable the collection of testimonies and improve responsiveness. STOP homophobie has also launched several websites to provide information on LGBT+ issues. They expect to launch a free license website with educational materials to raise awareness among educational staff and students. By supporting this project, you enable victims to receive at least 2 sessions of medical and psychological treatment.

name_en: Inspire young people to take action for sustainability
short_description_en: The Imagine School Program of the Projet Imagine Association aims at raising awareness amongst students through education in order to create responsible and committed citizens in a sustainable and inclusive society.
description_en: Through the ISP program «Imagine School Program», the association Projet Imagine seeks to raise awareness of citizenship and sustainable development among children and youth. The program is implemented in France and is open to all schools, public and private, from kindergarten to high school. Once trained by the ISP team, the teacher co-leads or facilitates the sessions which aim at reinforcing the notions of social and collective responsibility. The program takes place in 3 phases: 1) the Inspiration phase: a journey that leads the student to self-discovery; 2) the Action phase: students develop their group project using project management methodological tools; and 3) the Implementation phase of the sustainable development project in partnership with local associations (e.g.: Unicef Nord, UL of the Red Cross in Bobigny, etc.). Your support will enable 336 students from 12 classes to attend this program.

name_en: Support vulnerable women in situation of job insecurity
short_description_en: Inmigrant women face greater employment barriers, hindering their personal growth as well as their ability to integrate into society. Without the right support, these barriers can push them into extreme poverty. This project seeks to empower vulnerable women facing job insecurity or precarious work in Paris suburbs.
description_en: Gribouilli, the first professional association for childcare in the area of Paris, was created to professionalize and promote early childhood careers. Among the women who babysit at home, many are single mothers, with an immigrant background and sometimes considered 'senior'. With Gribouilli, they can train through a program of workshops and benefit from individual follow-ups to better manage their professional career. They can also be part of a community, become 'Ambassadors' of Gribouilli and get involved in responsible functions of the association. Gribouilli´s program 'Training-Action' is part of their targeted professionalization activities and is designed for nannies that experience job insecurity. Through a series of workshops over the course of a month, 9 women get training on employability skills and receive professional counseling. From learning how to write a CV to contract negotiation strategies: the training program prepares nannies for a successful insertion in the labor market. Great emphasis is also placed on coping mechanisms women can adapt to better deal with the negative impacts of the health crisis on employment.

name_en: Improve the living conditions of slum dwellers
short_description_en: Urban slum communities in the Philippines face a high crime rate as well as a rapid spread of infectious diseases, especially due to poor hygiene practices. The pandemic has exacerbated the poverty situation of many families, who are unable to maintain adequate hygiene to protect themselves from infectious diseases andCOVID-19. The Eau et Vie association distributes hygiene kits to vulnerable populations and conducts awareness-raising workshops.
description_en:
Eau et vie is committed to improving the living conditions of those who need it most. Across the Philippines, the French association distributes hygiene kits to dwellers of urban slums. They aim at spreading awareness about the importance of good hygiene practices, in order to prevent infectious diseases.

The association has developed three kits, which are always distributed alongside the realization of awareness-raising sessions. A hygiene kit (soap and masks), a personal hygiene kit for children (toothpaste, toothbrush, towel and soap) and a menstrual hygiene kit for women who are extremely precarious in this regard (sanitary napkins and soap).

Workshops take place in schools. Most of these sessions are aimed at a young audience, who can adopt the knowledge in a more sustainable way.

name_en: Support children in SOS villages to succeed at school
short_description_en: The aim of SOS Villages d’Enfants in terms of educational support is to enable each child it welcomes in a village to progress towards academic success. Considering academic difficulties are often linked to the living and home situation, the association intends to do everything possible to promote the success of the children it supports.
description_en:
Unable to remain in their family environment, children removed from their parents by decision of the judge need special care and attention. They generally have irregular school paths, often experience school delays and tend to focus mostly on short professional cycles.

Aware of this reality, SOS Villages d’Enfants has developed the 'Pygmalion program' for academic success. It has been deployed since 2014 in the 17 SOS Villages in France, welcoming 1000 children in total. This program aims at preventing dropouts and school failures as well as reconciling children with school. It also focuses on increasing the number of completed school courses or diplomas obtained and reduces school gaps.

To do this, it provides individualized support for each child through a school educator, hours of school tutoring and educational projects to develop children's cognitive and psychomotor skills.

name_en: Support the inclusion of exiled people through green skills
short_description_en: As in other European countries, the social and professional integration of refugees poses a major challenge for France. The EKO! Association reconciles efforts to promote the integration of these people with efforts to protect the environment. This program helps refugees develop green skills through the construction of low-tech systems.
description_en:
The Low-tech and Refugees program contributes to improving the resilience and autonomy of exiled people, while contributing to the ecological transition of the territory. The program is implemented by EKO! in the island of Lesbos in Greece and in the cities of Marseille and Briançon in France.

In France, the program disseminates ecological and technical know-how and supports the socio-professional integration of exiled people through ecological jobs. In the collaborative workshops, refugees learn how to build low tech systems which have a low cost and are made out of recyclable and renewable materials. Non-exiled people also participate in the association's workshops which fosters bonding with exiled members.

The low-tech workshops focus on eco-skills such as bicycle repair, creation of pallet furniture or solar cooking. Each participant leaves with a technical knowledge and a concrete and/or reproducible realization, which will be useful in their daily life. Moreover, sustainable jobs in the construction, agriculture, and energy sectors are in full expansion, which represents a great opportunity for the integration for exiled people.

name_en: Prevent plastic from entering rivers and oceans
short_description_en: Our planet is drowning in plastic pollution. 80% of all the plastic ever produced has ended up in the natural environment, especially in our oceans. The environmental impact of plastic pollution threatens marine ecosystems, human food security, and contributes to global warming. This project supports the collection and upcycling of plastic waste from rivers and oceans, while raising awareness about plastic pollution in France and abroad.
description_en: 80% of plastic pollution in the oceans comes from the rivers and streams that flow into them. Octop’us is implementing actions to raise citizens' awareness on the impact of their consumption habits on the environment and more particularly on the oceans. Through clean-up days and awareness sessions in schools and businesses, Octop’us provides action keys to those who want to act for the ecological transition. Hosted in an alternative third location, Octop’us has installed a low-tech waste recovery machine to give a second life to plastic objects collected by citizens. It offers a concrete solution to act for plastic pollution reduction. The plastic is collected, sorted and transformed into objects which are either kept by the participants or sold in order to finance other pollution control actions in France and abroad.

name_en: Reduce child malnutrition
short_description_en: Malnutrition is one of the main causes of infant mortality in low income countries. Children who suffer malnutrition have major learning difficulties. This Mozambique-based program aims to improve the dietary practices and living conditions of vulnerable children under 6 years.
description_en: In the rural municipalities of Massaca and Mahanhane, in southern Mozambique, 47 children under 6 years of age have been identified as highly vulnerable. They belong to very unstructured families, they have malnutrition problems, and do not have access to a qualitative education. Our team in Mozambique intends to carry out personalized monitoring of these children, under the supervision of community health agents and the participation of the Massaca and Mahanhane children's centers, thus guaranteeing their most basic rights. The main objective of the project is the reduction of diseases linked to child malnutrition (anemia, infections, rickets, etc.) in the beneficiary children.

name_en: Restore and protect coral reefs
short_description_en: Global warming, pollution, and human activities threaten the health of marine ecosystems and put biodiversity at risk. Reefscapers aims to restore coral reefs and marine habitats in the Maldives, using their innovative coral frame technique.
description_en:
Reefscapers aims to fight coral reef biodiversity loss and coastal erosion by efficiently restoring altered reefs and deserted sandy seabeds in the Maldives. This project takes place in the Goidhoo Atoll, situated on the west of the Maldives atoll chain.

Although coral propagation is not new, Reefscapers has created an innovative propagation technique using pyramid-shaped coral frames which contribute to corals’ rapid growth. The project involves long-term monitoring and maintenance. All the coral frames are biannually monitored, with pictures taken and uploaded to their website.

Moreover, the team is working towards the development of ever more resistant coral offspring, better adapted to withstand higher seawater temperatures, and so help the corals in their fight against global warming.

name_en: Support women refugees in Kampala
short_description_en: Uganda hosts more than 1.4 million refugees, 86% of whom are women and children. These women often provide for their households on their own. Self-help groups run by the refugees themselves are essential in supporting them. This project reinforces these local organizations, such as SWPDA which supports 600 refugee women from South Sudan in Uganda.
description_en: The French NGO, Urban Refugee (UR), has developed an incubator to support refugee-led associations such as SWPDA, a project providing help to South Sudanese refugee women and their families. Through Urban Refugee’s support, refugee-led initiatives, such as SWPDA, receive technical and financial support. They work directly with refugee leaders to enhance their ability to provide for their communities and achieve long-term sustainability. UR’s support activities include, among others, facilitating training on fundraising, financial and project management, and partnership development. The Ugandan female-led association, SWPDA, supports over 600 Sudanese refugee women and their children. They offer a safe shelter to female survivors of sexual and gender-based violence, support community newcomers with the refugee registration process and provide food during Ramadan.

name_en: Offer language courses to foster integration of exiled people
short_description_en: Lack of French language skills undermines the possibilities of refugees and asylum seekers to find adequate jobs and, overall, hinders a successful integration. The association UniR offers language courses adapted to this audience’s needs using a blended learning methodology.
description_en:
UniR’s FLE 2.0 program aims to enable refugees and asylum seekers to learn French through blended learning, in order to secure their professional integration in a sustainable way. Students have access to more than 120 hours of online exercises, in addition to 30 hours face-to-face with a teacher.

Thanks to the participation of two experienced teachers, students benefit from a continuous and personalized pedagogical follow-up. UniR's program offers quality, effective courses that meet the specific needs of refugees and asylum seekers who want to take control of their future and make the most of their past experiences. Students have access to courses at A2, B1 and B2 levels.

Since 2019, UniR has organized 5 courses for 225 refugees and asylum seekers.

name_en: Collect, recycle and upcycle waste
short_description_en: The global municipal waste production weights over 2 billion tons per year. In sub-Saharan Africa, waste production will increase by 70% by 2050. A disaster as there's currently no infrastructure there to support it. This project supports vulnerable Togolese women to develop innovative waste management initiatives. From collection to upcycling.
description_en:
Entrepreneurs du Monde's MIAWODO program aims to contribute to the economic development of vulnerable populations in Togo. The project supports the creation and development of micro-businesses, especially those delivering a positive environmental impact. As part of the program, unskilled young people living in poor areas of Lomé get access to vocational training in waste management. Beneficiaries carry out innovative activities such as waste collection, sorting, recycling, and upcycling and participate in awareness-raising sessions.

MIAWODO is an innovative program as it strengthens the local economy through employment while tackling waste pollution. Beneficiaries get the opportunity to develop waste and business management skills that either helps them to create their own sustainable business or qualify for green jobs. Waste collection activities are followed by transformation ones: organic (composting), green waste (shredding), plastics (transformation into hydrocarbons), and tires and solar lamps (recycling). The project is also contributing to improving local people's health as it prevents waste from being dumped in the streets or burned.

name_en: Offer eye care services to children with visual problems
short_description_en: In France, 1 child out of 7 suffers from a visual disorder and 80% of learning is dependent on sight. Despite comprehensive health coverage in France, many barriers to care persist. Since 2018, the Helen Keller association aims to raise awareness, prevent and treat visual disorders in schoolchildren in the priority neighborhoods of the city of Nanterre.
description_en:
The Hellen Keller Europe (HKE) association enables vulnerable school-age children to get access to eye care services in order to perform better at school. Although health care is universal in France, there are still many access barriers such as long delays in seeing an ophthalmologist, the prohibitive cost of glasses, and a complex health care path. This is especially true for families in priority districts.

Through the PlanVue program, local orthoptists examine students’ eyesight at school to diagnose visual disorders. If a problem is detected, the subsequent medical examination is performed in the presence of the child’s parents, who also participate in awareness-raising sessions about the importance of visual health and prevention. Likewise, school staff gets trained in the early detection of eyesight problems.

If requested, HKE offers direct support to families throughout the medical pathway established in order to prevent them from not continuing their children's treatment. Each child can select and receive 2 pairs of eyeglasses.

name_en: Plant trees, restore mangroves and fight climate change
short_description_en: Almost 100 million hectares of forests have disappeared worldwide over the last 20 years. Reforestation projects restore forests, contribute to biodiversity preservation and mitigate climate change. This project focuses on Madagascar mangrove, a specific ecosystem where fishes can reproduce.
description_en: Madagascar is a nation with over 200,000 species of plants and animals that don’t exist anywhere else in the world. But more than 90% of Madagascar’s original forests have been destroyed, displacing entire animal species, and taking away the Malagasy’s ability to farm and live on the land. Entire mangrove estuaries are gone, leaving the bare earth to wash away into the sea. Eden has initiated the Madagascar Reforestation Project in 2007 and has now successfully planted over 347 million mangrove and dry deciduous trees. Eden Reforestation Projects works collaboratively with many different communities with full support from national, local, and tribal governments to reforest large areas of forests along coastal and inland areas. Eden will provide training and financial support to the local community to collect mangrove propagules and strategically plant millions of trees in coastal mangrove systems and upland dry deciduous forests that have been heavily degraded or deforested.

name_en: Protect the Amazon’s biodiversity and local economies
short_description_en: The Amazon is home to more than 1.4 million plant and animal species, almost half of those on the planet. However, its deforestation continues, caused mainly by illegal logging, intensive agriculture, and cattle breeding. Envol Vert’s project protects 40.000 hectares by improving local communities’ living conditions.
description_en:
Envol Vert implements a regional program aiming at protecting the biodiversity in a 40,000 hectare reserve in the heart of the Peruvian Amazon while improving the living conditions of local communities.

The project takes place in Junin and Huánuco regions and supports the development of economic alternatives for local communities. By doing so, they fight poverty and prevent illegal deforestation. Through their participation in the program, farmers learn new production models based on agroforestry. It is an environmentally friendly agricultural system in which trees are grown among crops or pastureland.

The transition towards agroforestry-based agriculture prevents the use of herbicides that over time diminish the productivity of plots, destroy biodiversity and force farmers to engage in indiscriminate logging. The program enhances the economic resilience of farmers by diversifying their production with local fruits varieties - açaí and tropical nuts. Beyond training in sustainable harvesting, beneficiaries learn processing practices as well as in packaging and marketing techniques.

name_en: Protect coral reefs and support local communities
short_description_en: There is no doubt the world is undergoing an environmental and social crisis, in part due to climate change but also to local stressors. This is why Coral Guardian spreads its knowledge by teaming up with local communities and NGOs to protect marine biodiversity in the Mediterranean Sea.
description_en:
SOS Corales is a project that responds to the problem of degradation of marine species in the region of Punta de la Mona, Spain; a problem that is linked to an increase in pollution of the Mediterranean Sea. Coral Guardian implements the project in close collaboration with the Spanish NGO, Equilibrio Marino.

The project aims to ensure the restoration of coral beds, which will contribute to the return of biodiversity to the damaged areas and, thus, impact the lives of the local populations that depend on them. The creation of local jobs allows the development of economic models in the region and ensures the sustainability of the project. By enhancing marine ecosystems, the SOS Corales project provides coastal communities with solutions to the problem of marine resource degradation.

Monthly monitoring of the number of transplanted corals, mortality and growth rates, and the return of biodiversity are carried out.

name_en: Impede plastic waste from entering the oceans
short_description_en: Over 8 million tons of plastic waste end up in the sea every year. This phenomenon is particularly strong in developing countries as they often lack the infrastructure for proper waste disposal. This project finances the fight against plastic through the carbon compensation made by a certified carbon offset project in the Philippines.
description_en:
Stopping ocean plastic while improving the lives of those who are most affected - this is the approach taken by the Plastic Bank project. In Haiti, Indonesia, Brazil and the Philippines, local communities are collecting plastic waste. At local collection points, they can exchange it for money, food, clean water or even school fees.

This project protects the climate while tackling plastic pollution. Per each ton of carbon compensated through a Gold Standard VER certified carbon offset project in the Philippines, 10 kgs of plastic waste (equivalent to 500 plastic bottles) will be prevented from entering the ocean. The carbon offset is done through the generation of emissions-free electricity in a wind farm on the Philippine island of Luzon.

Recycled plastic is turned into a so-called Social Plastic, which serves as raw material for new products such as packaging.

name_en: Plant fruits trees and protect the regional biodiversity
short_description_en: Climate change, deforestation, and the expansion of intensive monoculture agriculture threaten biodiversity and the health of forests. Envol Vert protects biodiversity and supports farmers in the transition towards more sustainable agricultural systems by planting native fruit trees in France.
description_en:
Envol vert’s program Au Pré de Mes Arbres aims to revalue the domestic and wild biodiversity of the Tarn region by involving as many citizens as possible in the planting process of ancient fruit tree varieties and the protection of many species of amphibians.

Direct beneficiaries are local farmers who implement agroforestry agriculture (an environmentally friendly agriculture system). This system allows them to consume and distribute local fruit varieties. The project also includes the creation of ecological corridors between forests, fruit tree plots, and wetlands as well as the restoration and creation of ponds. Two-third of the fruit trees will be chosen specifically for their resilience to expected extreme weather conditions in the coming years.

Envol Vert oversees the entire planting process: from land preparation to providing training to farmers and follow-up. The program also runs awareness-raising workshops with school-age children and local citizens to allow for the reappropriation of the local biodiversity.

name_en: Preserve a primary forest and protect wildlife
short_description_en: Forest areas in Kenya are home to exceptional wildlife and are the guarantors of the economic prosperity of the country. They are now strongly threatened. This project to protect and manage this exceptional national natural heritage is being carried out with the strong participation of local populations.
description_en: The cultural and ecological heritage of Kenya’s forests is vibrant and unique, but the management of them in recent decades has been unsustainable. Since 2019, Eden Reforestation Projects has been working in the 5,000-hectare protected Kijabe Forest. The Kijabe Forest sits in a complex, dynamic landscape. About 1.5 hours from Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, the forest grows on the Great Rift Valley’s steep edges. Once home to herds of buffalo, leopard, and elephant, this forest is an essential home and corridor for wildlife. Animals use this area to move between the dry floor of the Rift Valley and the protected, lush forests of the Kenyan highlands. As part of Kenya’s five nationally significant water towers, the forest channels water to surrounding communities and the country as a whole. Eden partners with the Kijabe Forest Trust, regional and national government institutions, and the surrounding agricultural and pastoral communities to restore this vital forest.

In response to the COVID crisis Conexus will also support entrepreneurs to pivot their existing business models in order to remain sustainable and socially impactful in our new reality. Each entrepreneur will be paired with a local mentor who will accompany them throughout the 4 month program as well as an expert student consultant who will support the entrepreneur with specific needs such as budgeting and marketing. name_en: Heal the Mediterranean Sea
short_description_en: The Mediterranean Sea is recognized as a biodiversity hotspot. However, pollution & climate change affect this amazing ecosystem. This project promotes the restoration of coastal zones as well as the conservation of endangered marine species; in southern Spain.
description_en: This project aims to safeguard endangered marine species, and particularly those that protect coastal ecosystems such as the seahorse, on the Spanish Mediterranean coast, in the Alboran Sea, in Malaga and Granada. Coastal areas are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change, due to the heavy occupation of the coastline, affecting the very dynamics of beaches. This occupation leads to the gradual disappearance of seagrass beds. Restoring these seagrass beds and their associated fauna will help mitigate the effects of climate change, acting as natural barriers against waves and storms, reducing sand loss on beaches, producing oxygen, filtering and clarifying waters, fixing CO2, and serving as areas of refuge and reproduction of an enormous marine and coastal biodiversity.

name_en: Improving health conditions through drinking water access
short_description_en: Two billion people in the world have no access to drinkable water. Many families have to boil their water over an open fire, resulting in CO₂ emissions and deforestation. This project aims to solve this issue, by repairing and maintaining  boreholes, thus improving access to drinkable water sources.
description_en: This project addresses the daily challenges of rural communities in Gatsibo, Rwanda by repairing and maintaining existing boreholes to improve their access to drinkable water. The quality of water in Rwanda is not safe to drink. Families must either boil water over wood-fuelled fires, resulting in respiratory illnesses, or travel hour-long distances to reach drinkable sources. In fact, many communities have boreholes, however, they often lack the capacities to maintain them over the years. This project aims at restoring and repairing existing boreholes to provide clean drinkable water to Rwandan communities. Each borehole is up to 100 metres deep and operated with a simple hand pump. For each ton of CO₂ compensated, local people get access to 5,000 liters of clean water.

description_en: Equine-assisted therapy (EAT) is a therapeutic and social tool. It acts as a complementary therapy and alternative care to the usual, educational and social therapies, and is provided at the heart of the Marie-Hélène Association's medical and social establishments. It is an essential component of a global therapeutic project, adapted to the needs of each beneficiary, and in collaboration with their families. The association aims at providing life-long support to their community by ensuring their well-being and monitoring their progress. They foster the inclusion of handicap people. Concretely, an EAT-session allows for several approaches -work on the ground around the horse or horseback riding- as well as a customizable duration. This project allows 100 handicap people to get access to at least 5 EAT-sessions.

description_en: Sport dans la Ville's program called Passe Décisive targets young people between 16 and 25 years of age who have dropped out of school, are unemployed, untrained and come from disadvantaged neighborhoods in the Ile-de-France and the Grand Lyon region. The association identifies these young people who have dropped out of school (through local agents, families, the employment office, etc.) and offers them support adapted to their needs so that they can acquire the skills and knowledge necessary for their professional (re)insertion. name_en: Bringing drinking water directly to the homes of slum dwellers
short_description_en: Today, 55% of urban households in Bangladesh reside in slums, without access to essential services, and only 45% of the urban population has access to a safely managed water supply. Eau et Vie creates local social water distribution companies, with the objective of providing disadvantaged families with a connection to drinking water at home.
description_en:
In slums, the lack of essential services coupled with high population density exacerbates the spread of disease, environmental degradation, and significant inequalities among the most disadvantaged populations. The objective of Eau et Vie is to improve the living and health conditions of families living in the slums of Dhaka and Chattogram, the two largest cities in Bangladesh, through sustainable access to safe drinking water at home.

Eau et Vie creates local social water distribution companies. The social enterprise builds a water network connected to that of the city concessionaire and distributes water in the underprivileged urban district by providing all associated services: reading meters, collecting payments, maintaining and securing the network. The company operates in areas where the official operator fails to work according to its profitability standards. 80% of the staff (plumbers, collectors, encoders, etc.) are recruited from the intervention areas where the agencies are located, dynamizing the local economy and guaranteeing the project's sustainability.

Donations collected through the NooS platform aim at providing access to drinking water to 250 vulnerable people.

name_en: Feed the vulnerable children of Madagascar
short_description_en: In Madagascar, 47% of children under 5, approximately 2 millions children, are chronically malnourished. The country is experiencing a serious food crisis caused by drought and aggravated by the Covid-19 pandemic. This project supports school canteens to limit malnutrition of Malgasy children.
description_en:
In Madagascar, SOS Villages d’Enfants has put together various programs to help the most vulnerable children and families.

This project supports the school canteens of SOS schools in Madagascar, which benefit more than 4,000 children. They provide 1 healthy and balanced meal per day, which is often the only meal of the day for these children. They also allow them to benefit from nutritional and medical monitoring, in addition to being able to access quality education.

The children attending the 7 SOS schools and training centers are children from very vulnerable families. Thus, this program also contributes to strengthening the whole family around the following themes: education, health, family support, socio-economic recovery of the family or access to rights, for example.

name_en: Foster the integration of vulnerable children through sports
short_description_en: Initiated in 2012, this Sports Development Program has two main objectives. First, it wishes to promote the physical and psychological development of children and young people accommodated in SOS villages. Then, it aims at strengthening their social integration and their autonomy. The achievement of these objectives is based on the activities offered, such as horse riding, multisport or hiking.
description_en:
SOS Villages d’Enfants welcomes children separated from their parents for serious family reasons. Because of their family history, these more vulnerable children often have difficulty finding their place in society. They develop a negative self-image and have low self-confidence.

This Sports Development Program, created in 2012, aims at supporting these young people in a different way. Indeed, it uses sport and the sharing of common experiences as educational levers to support teenagers in difficulty, promote their self-development and their social integration.

This program is divided into 2 parts. First, children get access to group sports courses (hiking, aquatic activities, horse riding, and body expression) which are offered during 3 courses per year during the school holidays. Then, it also offers individual support for 20 teenagers in great difficulty each year.

This program enables each child to work on their difficulties by having activities chosen according to their needs. For example, skills like autonomy, decision-making, self-care are reinforced through hiking activities.

name_en: Deliver food to the victims of the natural disaster in La Palma
description_en:
Over the past three months, the volcanic eruption on La Palma has disrupted the lives of more than 83,000 inhabitants of the island. As of today, 1,646 buildings have been buried by the volcano's lava, mostly houses, forcing more than 7,000 people to be evacuated. The natural disaster has increased the number of vulnerable families, many of whom had not yet managed to recover from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

In this context, the NGO Sonrisas Canarias has decided to join forces with other organizations and public entities to provide humanitarian aid to the affected families. Since the beginning of the eruption, the local NGO has delivered food (vegetables, fruits, various kinds of meat) and non-perishable food and personal care and cleaning products through the program Todos somos La Palma (We are all La Palma).

The NGO not only seeks to offer immediate help to the affected families but also to boost the local economy by supporting the affected local businesses. The Sonrisas Canarias team gives shopping vouchers to the families, who can use them in small stores.

name_en: Plant bamboo to fight climate change
short_description_en: This project is tackling deforestation in a very innovative way, by planting bamboo, rather than trees, as they regenerate rapidly and absorb large quantities of carbon.
description_en: This project in eastern Nicaragua planted more than one million plants of a native species of giant bamboo, covering 2,361 hectares while protecting 1,000 hectares of primary forest. This project helps limit deforestation by replacing the cutting of trees with the harvesting of bamboo that regenerates more easily. Indeed, bamboo is particularly effective in the fight against climate change because it absorbs CO₂, which helps lower temperatures, create microclimates and promote the biosphere. Furthermore, bamboo fiber is a sustainable material and is increasingly used in industry, providing economic opportunities for local and vulnerable populations.

name_en: Bringing society together around a meal
short_description_en: Our society tends to create social bubbles: with Les Petites Cantines, promote the gathering of our society and allow enriching exchanges around a table, where everyone pays for their meal according to their means.
description_en:
The feeling of loneliness has become a common phenomenon in France, since according to the Fondation de France, 7 million people, i.e. 14% of the population, find themselves in a situation of isolation.

The health crisis has only exacerbated this loneliness. Young people, who had previously been spared, have been largely affected by social exclusion with the successive confinements and closure of socialising places.

The increase in the feeling of mistrust towards others is also one of the reasons for the growth of solitude in France.

Promoting proximity and social ties has become a priority. To this end, the network of small canteens allows anyone, isolated or not, disadvantaged or not, to come and share a participatory meal at a free price. On site, one or more paid hostesses supervise the canteen and run the place, with the support of a team of volunteers.

The opening of a new Petite Cantine within the network will allow nearly 2000 additional members to benefit from this valuable source of socialisation.

The opening of this small canteen also responds to the issue of sustainable food, since everything is home-made and all the products are sourced from short and organic circuits.

Finally, opening a new Petite Cantine means participating in the snowball effect aimed at by the association, allowing the project to spread and thus contributing to the more inclusive city of tomorrow.

short_description_en: Télémaque, which supports secondary school students and apprentices through a comprehensive mentoring programme, has set up additional support for the sponsored chil experiencing educational difficulties. This consists of support courses in the necessary subjects.
description_en:
France is one of the most unequal countries in the OECD in terms of education. It takes an average of six generations for the descendants of modest families to reach the average income, which puts France in second place before Hungary (OECD 2018).

However, social determinism is not a fatality, and appropriate support can change the lines.

For more than 15 years, Télémaque has been fighting for equal opportunities by promoting the educational success of young people from disadvantaged areas through comprehensive and personalised support. The sponsored child benefit from double mentoring, educational activities and financial aid.

The health crisis has made the situation of young people experiencing difficulties at school even worse. Distance learning, insecurity, an unfavourable working environment, feelings of isolation and psychological fragility have only aggravated the educational breakdowns.

To compensate for this worsening of the situation, Télémaque has set up a programme of support courses in the subjects that are lacking for the godchildren who are experiencing difficulties.

name_en: Supporting young people leaving the Children's Social Aid system
short_description_en: For young people protected by the Children’s Social Aid system, coming of age means the end of their care and thus constitutes a period of vulnerability often characterised by precariousness and exclusion. La Touline supports them in all areas of access to autonomy and pays particular attention to their emotional well-being.
description_en:
Under child protection, children and adolescents who cannot be maintained in their families are cared for by the Children’s Social Aid System. Coming of age means the end of care for them. The transition to adulthood, a period of vulnerability for all young people, is even more so for those leaving child protection care. Emotionally and materially deprived, these young people find themselves in situations of precariousness and exclusion. To give just one figure, 40% of homeless people come out of the Child Welfare system.

The mission of La Touline is to accompany these young people through this difficult transition and to aim for their long-term reintegration.La Touline provides a space for dialogue and encounters that encourage them to become more human. It provides them with personal support in the various areas of access to autonomy and adult life (health, housing, training, work, emotional life, etc.). This support is provided in close collaboration with the mainstream networks and a network of private partners.

La Touline capitalises on the link, the human relationship created with these young people, to invent and build with them a personalised and punctual support. The objective is to enable these young people to feel that they can "count on and count for".

name_en: Upcycle plastic waste and support refugees
short_description_en: Our planet is drowning in plastic. 80% of all the plastic ever produced has ended up in the natural environment, especially in our oceans. The environmental impact of plastic pollution threatens marine ecosystems and contributes to global warming. Octop’us supports the collection and upcycling of plastic waste from rivers and oceans, while raising awareness about plastic pollution in France and abroad.
description_en:
Thanks to Octop’us activities the world is a cleaner place! Octop’us collects and upcycle plastic waste; plastic is reconditioned and turned into objects such as furniture (chairs, tables, etc.). Plastic is collected from voluntary drop-off points strategically placed in schools, universities, companies and the streets of Strasbourg.

The collected waste is then directly transformed in their Fablab, based in the Port du Rhin district. Concerned about the need to find alternatives to waste recycling, Octop'us promotes their transformation in short circuit and with LowTech methods, using little energy to valorize the plastic material. Refugees and asylum seekers are invited to be part of the upcycling activities as a way to foster their integration.

The association is part of the Precious Plastic community which grants them access to LowTech machines and training on plastic waste upcycling. By placing bins all over the city, they aim at also raising awareness about plastic pollution and making citizens actors of the ecological transition, including those in very precarious or excluded situations.

name_en: Provide drinking water access to vulnerable communities
short_description_en: Sierra Leone is a largely rural country where households typically use wood fuel on inefficient three-stone fires to purify their drinking, cleaning, and washing water. This process results in the release of greenhouse gas emissions from the combustion of wood – however, these emissions can be avoided by using efficient borehole technology that does not require fuel to supply clean water.
description_en:
Donating to this project means avoiding CO2 emissions while improving the access to clean water of communities in Kono, Sierra Leone.

This carbon offset project is restoring 57 wells in cooperation with the local population. Damaged wells are repaired and regularly maintained, which secures the regional water supply. The availability of clean drinking water eliminates the need to boil water, saving an average of 10,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions per year.

The project does not only contribute to climate action but also impacts gender equality. Girls and women are particularly affected by poor water conditions due to the responsibility of household water supply. Providing clean water through boreholes reduces their time spent collecting water and firewood, which can now be used for education or additional income.

name_en: Support the digitalization of quality education for vulnerable students
short_description_en: 10 percent of school pupils are leaving school without passing any exams in France, especially those coming from poor areas. These students often face social stigma, fewer job opportunities, and lower salaries. Thanks to the work of the 2nd Chance Schools (E2C) network , they learn in demand skills to thrive in their professional careers.
description_en:
For young people aged 16 to 25 who have dropped out of the school system, the Second Chance Schools (E2C) offers an intensive program (7 months on average), which combines work-study support, training, and resocialization.

This project supports the strengthening of online tools such as Open Distance Learning (E2C online classroom) to grant students access to high quality training. Although face-to-face presence in E2Cs is of particular importance to guarantee a personalized experience, the health crisis has accelerated reflections around the digitization of courses.

The platform has been developed to offer individualized educational courses following the quality guidelines of classroom courses. Students are also instructed in "learning how to learn" independently to guarantee a successful experience.

Beyond acquiring relevant hard skills in subjects such as computer sciences, students regain self-confidence through mentorship sessions. A series of internships help them discover professions and define their professional choice.

name_en: Contribute to the professional insertion of disadvantaged women
short_description_en: India has one of the highest rates of extreme poverty in the world: more than 20% of the population lives below the threshold of $1.90 per day and 30% of young adults are neither in school nor employed. Since 2009, LP4Y supports young people in rural areas facing extreme poverty. Beneficiaries get access to employability training in LP4Y’s training centers: the Green Villages.
description_en:
Life Project 4 Youth (LP4Y) specializes in helping young adults (17 to 24 years old) who are victims of exclusion and extreme poverty to find employment. The Green Village in West Bengal aims to accompany young women towards their sustainable integration through experiential learning and the development of their professional projects.

The West Bengal Green Village exclusively welcomes women, including young mothers, who come from different rural areas of the region or from the slums of Kolkata. For 3 months, they manage the Green Village engaging in micro-economic activities and, thus, acquire essential skills adapted to the business world (adaptability, professional behavior, teamwork, project management...).

Through the development of local partnerships and the organization of professional exposure activities with business actors, these young women create links with the world of decent employment for the first time. Women get empowered, develop environmental and civic awareness and can integrate themselves in a sustainable way socially and professionally, improving their living conditions and those of their entourage.

Thanks to donations collected through NooS, 193 women will get their basic needs met throughout the participation in the program (accomodation, hygiene products, food, etc.).

name_en: Train refugee people in low-tech development
short_description_en: The island of Lesbos hosted until September 2020 the largest refugee camp in Europe. Despite its closure, thousands of refugees are still waiting for a response to their asylum applications, in precarious conditions. EKO! seeks to improve the living conditions of refugees. The association empowers refugee people through the construction of low-tech systems that help them meet their immediate needs while contributing to the environment.
description_en:
The Low-tech with Refugees program contributes to improving the resilience and autonomy of exiled people, while contributing to the ecological transition of the territory. The program is implemented by EKO! in the island of Lesbos in Greece and in the cities of Marseille and Briançon in France.

In Greece, refugee people living in Lesbos-based camps meet at EKO!’s makerspace where they get access to training on low-technologies systems (LTS). Low-technologies are simple technical solutions that meet essential needs (i.e. energy production and conservation). They are accessible and respectful of the environment as renewable or recycled materials are used. For instance, refugees learn how to make wood-saving cookstoves, power-banks, windmills, among other devices that improve their daily lives. Horizontal learning through 'doing' is the key.

Through the program, EKO! supports refugee people in the development of life-changing skills that will enable a better professional integration, especially in green jobs. The makerspace is also a place where social interaction and learning help to lessen the burden of their difficult living situation.

name_en: Foster integration through sustainable fashion training
short_description_en: The French fashion industry imports 97% of its resources. The textile industry has lost 90% of its workforce. In the face of increasing dependency risks as well as the environmental impact of mass import and the social impact of exploitative work, the upcycling sewing course trains unemployed people in sustainable fashion.
description_en:
The future of fashion goes hand in hand with an ecological and social transition towards a more Sustainable, Accountable, Innovative and Circular fashion industry. Today, the carbon impact of a product made in France is 50% less than that of a product made in China.

With the aim of building a self-sufficient French textile industry and avoiding mass import, Fashion Green Hub trains unemployed people in industrial sewing - focusing particularly on sustainability and reusing materials - and supports them in their job search.

The training programme is called “Couture Upcycling” and is delivered in small groups of 6 people. In 60 days, participants learn to master the transformation of clothes, household linen in overstock into simple objects. The course takes place at the Plateau Fertile’s studio in Roubaix, in the City’s Priority District. The 60 days are divided into 30 days of training and 30 days of coached internship in a running garment factory. The participants learn how to dismantle, cut and tailor (laptop sleeves, bags, cases, etc). Following this training, participants are supported in their job search within the Fashion Green Hub network or in integrating further professional training.

name_en: Support indigenous peoples in their forests’ protection
short_description_en: Forests are one of the planet’s most important carbon reservoirs, home to a wide variety of species and provide a livelihood for many. However, in recent decades, global forest areas have sharply decreased- Together with local populations, this project aims to preserve Colombian forests in the long term.
description_en:
Forests play a crucial role in regulating climate. They cover 31% of the Earth’s surface and are the planet’s second largest carbon sink.

Preserving existing forests is one of the best solutions to maintain carbon absorption and sequestration processes.

The project follows a holistic approach for lasting shifts towards sustainable economic practices and forest conservation and protection. The project focuses on reducing indigenous territories’ vulnerability working hand-in-hand with local communities by constantly informing and training them - therefore improving living conditions and promoting sustainable economic growth.

Together with local populations, project participants protect the region from negative influences. To do so, the project generates alternative income sources and provides health services and educational opportunities to the communities involved.

The project represents:
  • 1,150,200 hectares of protected tropical forests
  • 3 622 000 tonnes of absorbed CO2 per year

name_en: Clean solar energy for Namibia
short_description_en: Solar energy is emission-free. Produced from photovoltaic cells, it does not require using fossil fuels. Developing solar energy production is essential to limit global warming and secure energy supplies. This project develops solar plants near the town of Gobabis in Namibia.
description_en:
Namibia imports more than 60% of its energy from the South African energy pool - which is mainly supplied by fossil-fuel power plants. To reduce this dependence, Omaheke’s carbon offset project near the town of Gobabis in Namibia uses the sun as an climate-friendly energy source: the solar plants built in 2017 include 18,560 PV solar modules and have a total capacity of 12.064 MW. As a result, 26,1 GWh of electricity are provided to the Namibian power grid annually. This sustainable energy production saves about 25,760 tonnes of CO2 emissions per year.

In addition to reducing emissions and improving Namibia’s energy self-sufficiency, the project is improving the local labor market. Since construction began, 30 jobs have been created, at least 8 of which will be dedicated to the long-term operation and maintenance of the plant.

name_en: Protect forests on the Brazilian Amazon estuary
short_description_en: Illegal deforestation is one of the major issues contributing to the destruction of forests, especially in Brazil. When trees are cut down, their stored carbon is released into the air as carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming. This project aims at protecting Amazonian forests by creating alternative sources of income to local communities in order to disincentivize deforestation.
description_en: Protecting forests from deforestation is key when it comes to fighting climate change. Forests are not only among the planet's most important carbon reservoirs. They also are home to an enormous diversity of species and are the livelihood for all people. This biodiversity project is implemented in Pará, Brazil and it aims at protecting an area of more than 86,000 hectares of forest, while preventing deforestation. Together with the local population, project participants protect the area by creating alternative sources of income -for example by trading the açaí fruit- and educational opportunities. This project is certified by the Gold Standard VER carbon certification. Moreover, the project has a double impact: for each ton of  CO₂ compensated in Brazil, one tree will be planted in France.

name_en: Wind turbines to support communities in Northeast Brazil
short_description_en: Wind energy is considered clean since it does not involve burning fossil fuels. Developing wind energy is essential to limiting global warming and securing energy supplies for the future. By building and operating 14 wind power plants, this project contributes to the social, economic and environmental development of one of Brazil’s poorest regions.
description_en:
In Northeast Brazil, this clean wind energy project is making a difference for both the environment and the surrounding communities. By implementing and operating 14 wind power plants comprising 156 wind turbines, clean and renewable electricity is delivered to the Brazilian Interconnected System. The wind farms located within the Ventos do Araripe lll Complex have a total capacity of 357 MW.

This clean energy project reduces the greenhouse gas emissions that would have been emitted through fossil fuel-based electricity production. It saves up to 650,000 tons of CO2 annually. In addition to supplying sustainable and renewable energy, the project makes important contributions to the social development of the region. It helps improve water supply, health care and access to education for local communities.
